posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Justice in civilized societies means settling interpersonal disputes, containing those too dangerous to roam free, and in some cases punishing those guilty of heinous crimes. People in this thread are misunderstanding what grieving or parenthood is like: sadness doesn't automatically translate into thirst for vengeance. What matters for the parent is the lost child, they want to focus on them and their memories of the time spent with them. Many will want to forget or ignore the cause of death to protect from the painful emotions linked to it, to push it away as a form of coping. Many are also empathetic to a point where they wish others didn't have to encounter a similar tragedy, rather than seeking for vengeance.

Situations where the government instutionalizes vengeance are unjust by design, given the state selects to use its divine rule to satiate a common bloodthirst towards misdeeds, ignoring not only the emotions of the victim but also the humanity of the criminal. Humane incarcenation is neither fully just, as we by nature are imperfect beings, but proves better results while seeking to better match the needs of every citizen involved. I believe in a mixed method like other anons have suggested.

One of my buddies is a prison guard and from what he told me and stuff I've read about US prisons, if you treat someone like an animal, they're going to be like an animal. I'm not going to "coddle" a rapist or murderer, but you have to give them some aspects of dignity. They get decent healthful meals, good toilet and sink in their cell, and Idle hands are the Devil's workshop so have them focus on learning academics or a trade, do stuff in the prison workshop (heavily monitored of course), physical fitness, and some entertainment time like movies or the library.

They don't get a cell that's like a youth hostel that Norway gets. And inmates should also spend time reflecting on what they did to be in prison and the impact of their poor decisions. Prison should focus on the 3 R's: Rehabilitation, Reform, and Retaliation. While you're in prison, you do not have voting rights. You are still a human being and accorded most of your civil rights, but you have to be out of prison to vote.

If they're a non-violent offender who did something stupid like steal a car or did illegal drugs, they should be drilled with discipline and the tools to be readmitted back into society and never to do shit like that again. So Rehabilitation in this case and they can get those nice rooms.

Repeat non-violent offenders need serious wake-up calls. So Reform. They get the nice room, but have limited free time. It's gonna be treated like boot camp. Wake up, fix your bed, make sure your prison uniform is nice and neat, do assigned tasks, go to school or learn how to do a trade. Exercise daily and maybe 1-2 hours of downtime. No TV or Internet. Magazines, newspapers, and books allowed.

Retaliation is violent offenders who show no remorse or being contrite. They have to do hard time. They will be paid an adequate wage (no slave labor that the prison industry loves to do) for doing jobs as well as manual labor.

Justice is fairness. Honest answers only?

Christianity, ironically, got a really great start in Rome allowed itself like 300 years to basically: establish and institutionalize a formal church (copying heavily from the Roman State Religion it replaced), finalize what was and wasn't Christian heresy to get their story straight, before they took a crack at the greater body of Europe.
Christianity, in Rome at least, had the distinct ?weird? advantage in that compared to the Roman State Religion; Christianity was kind of atheistic. One singular God was functionally indiscernible from just not believing in any gods at all. This quality pissed off the government, obviously, but for the every day man in the city this was seen as significantly less stressful and convenient. One God meant you only had to worry about one God. Easy peasy.
Across Continental Europe Christianity was able to beat out the various folk-cults because of the aforementioned church they had established. Pagan folk-religions, by comparison, weren't unified, didn't have a theological "body of work" as we understand it, so whenever a Priest or a Cleric defeated a Druid or some Shaman in a rap-battle that was basically it for that community. Furthermore, Christianity didn't mind assimilating "ordained sites": building churches and wells on already established sacred pagan sites.

FINALLY, pagan religions are ultimately just a body of local/ethnic/national myths, folklore, and ancestor worship. Christianity on the other hand is fairly globohomo: it's a progressive religion that has no racial nor ethnic requirements for participation, worships an indescribable supreme God, and strongly encourages conversion while simultaneously demanding the absolution of all other forms of spirituality.

Crimea has limited fresh water resources, and this has been a longstanding challenge for the region. Before the annexation of Crimea by Russia in 2014, most of the peninsula's fresh water was supplied by the North Crimean Canal, which carried water from the Dnieper River in Ukraine to Crimea. However, following the annexation, Ukraine cut off the supply of water through the canal, and Russia has had to rely on other sources to meet the region's needs.

One solution that Russia has implemented is the construction of a new water pipeline, called the Taurida Pipeline, which brings water from the Krasnodar region on the mainland to Crimea. The Taurida Pipeline is designed to provide a reliable source of fresh water for the peninsula, and is expected to be able to meet the majority of Crimea's water needs.

We cannot know whether there is or isn't a god, but claims about a specific god can have (on a scale) evidence, a lack of evidence, and contradictory evidence.
One important thing to note is that if there is a continuing lack of evidence in an area that was claimed to be able to produce evidence (for instance, "prayer can heal physical ailments"), then this lack of evidence can be at least provisionally considered to be contradictory evidence.
On balance, it would appear that Yahweh has tiny nuggets of evidence mixed with largely a lack of evidence and some contradictory evidence, therefore it is unreasonable to believe in him unless you appeal to ulterior utilitarian motives.

Fascism is deliberately vague and hard-to-define.

>The Vagueness of the Fascist Programme: There are certain curious features about this Fascism. There has been no efficient fight against it, even when the danger has been understood long beforehand, and there is not yet even a satisfactory explanation of what Fascism is. The Fascists themselves have not been able to produce an intelligible definition. These difficulties are to a great extent due to the elusive character of Fascism itself. Fascism is not a clear-cut theory. It takes great pride in despising coherent theories and well-thought-out programmes.

>Mussolini used to say: ‘What we need is not a programme but action.’ Mosley in his early days took this as his slogan, and becomes the less effective the more he departs from this attitude. The Italian Fascists have always stressed what they call ‘dynamics’. Quite cheerfully, even in 1924, the Fascist Govi in the Critica Fascista (one of the theoretical organs of the Italian Fascist Party) could say: ‘Fascism is clear in its negative programme, but it is not clear in the least what is its programme in positive innovations.’

>In his early days, when he was preparing for his first bid for power, Hitler in a speech made in 1923 declared: ‘Let us first begin to rule, then the programme will come quite by itself.’ – a statement that would be received with roars of laughter in any Socialist or Liberal conference. But four years later he was saying significantly: ‘The people want no programmes. They want someone to rule them.’
-- Edward Conze & Ellen Wilkinson, 1935

Also Conze was a Marxist but that essay is interesting because it gives a different take than the usual "capitalism in decay" stuff.

>The Main Contradictions in Fascism: This vague, ambiguous, elusive character of the party which has been regarded as a main argument against Fascism supplies, in fact, the key to the understanding of it.

>We live in an age of transition – and that does not necessarily imply that the transition period is a brief one. The transition from feudal to capitalist society lasted approximately 400 years. The changeover from a horse to a horsepower civilisation has been going on for over a hundred years with all the changes and stresses in social structure that intensified mass production brings. The big jump that has now to be made is the changeover from an individualistic to a collective, from an anarchic to a planned economy.

>Fascism is the political form of one of the stages in this transition, that stage in which we now are. All the antagonistic and contradictory tendencies are somehow united in it. All the elements that feel the necessity of change, but want everybody to be changed except themselves and their own group, can project their wishes into the Fascist party, and find nothing there that is rigidly opposed to their wish phantasies. It is usual to reproach Hitler because he promised to everybody (except Jews) anything they wanted. Why reproach a leader for doing what his party exists to do? It is the strength of Fascism that it can take all the contradictory elements into itself. It is the weakness of Fascism, as of any other essentially reactionary system, that it attempts to solve these contradictions and can only do so on the basis of war preparation.
https://www.marxists.org/subject/fascism/conze-wilkinson/ch21.htm

>The Minor Contradictions in Fascism: Owing to the general contradictions within Fascism a number of minor contradictions exist. There is the inevitable struggle between the policy of preserving the ‘old’ middle classes, their local status and independence, and the desire for a plan which would make superfluous many functions that the old middle class performed. There is the contradiction between the attempt to lower the standard of the workers, dictated by the capitalist elements in Fascism, and the war preparations which need a reasonably contented working class. There is the incompatibility of autarchy and conquest of foreign markets: between the return to the village economy and war. The return to the village means the extinction of the heavy industry which is indispensable to the needs of the militarists. To see only one side of these contradictions as real, and to assume that the other is there for window-dressing purposes, makes it impossible to understand Fascism and the necessary zig-zaggery of Fascist policy.

>It is the Leader who keeps together and maintains the equilibrium between the contradictory elements and groups. Therefore each Fascist party has one thing at least in common... a leader. Hence the fanatical loyalty to his person, and the theatrical over-advertisement of the man. A myth grows round him. The conviction spreads that whatever seems confusing or disappointing will somehow be solved when the Leader has time to give it his personal and magical attention. >>14432409
From these pre-Incaic elements, the image could represent the ancient temple of Pachacamac, built in honor of the local god of the place, popular in much of the northern part of the Inca Empire, although the perspective seems more in line with the much larger and more recent Temple of the Sun built by the Incas.
The local non-Inca temple at Pachacamac was occupied by the Wari (among others), but when the Incas conquered the sactuary it was an Ichma temple and was painted with distinctive Ichma motifs (very diferent from Wari's), so it is also called the Painted Temple. In this temple survived a representation of the god Pachacamac, a wooden pole dating to the Wari period. As I said the Chavin were much older and all their sanctuaries and style had already been abandoned long ago, none surviving into the time of the Incas, not to mention that Chavin stone stelae are extremely rare and the few found are in the heart of Chavin, in its temple and nearby vicinity, not a single one has been found on the coast or so far away.

>>14432567
Knitting didn't exist in the pre-Columbian Andes, although they knew practically all other weaving techniques known today.

Similarly, ponchos appear to have been rare in comparison to today. Although they appear in some pre-Inca cultures (especially coastal ones) such as Paracas, for the most part they did not have the proportions of today's ponchos, the common attire of most highland provinces during the Inca empire was an uncu, which is a sleeveless tunic with a yacolla or blanket around it, which was still the common attire recorded in many parts in early colonial times, the rise in popularity of today's ponchos is rather hazy, but seems to have been an evolution of uncus from which the sides were left unstitched.

And what are we dealing with? After Tatar invasion, resettling the plundered land was important for the economy of kingdom. King or high nobility invited foreigners on their lands (in my country's case mainly Saxons). A wealthier individual (locator) brought new guests from abroad and with the consent of the landlord settled them on the depopulated land. In dependence of certain criteria new settlers got relief from paying all benefits and fees (deadline). After settling they paid a certain amount for the possibility to settle on new land and locator made a contract with the landlord, which granted all the rights and obligations of the new settlers. Privileged position in the new village was given to the hereditary magistrate - locator, who was granted a free strip of land, possibility to build mill, brewery, tavern or craft workshops on his property. Hereditary magistrate had also lower judicial authority and got a third of collected fines.

In 1992, Therressa took Samantha down to Kentucky and they lived there for two years before returning to Dayton. She had never bothered telling Denton about their move and claimed she did it because she needed some time to get her life together.

Not long after returning to Ohio, Therressa was arrested on an assault charge. On May 10, 1995, Denton filed a court petition to get custody of Samantha transferred to him. Despite Therressa's drug problems, a rap sheet, and living in squalid conditions, the Montgomery County Domestic Relations Court took her side in the custody dispute anyway and on July 11 declined Denton's request for custody of his daughter.

On August 5, Therressa and her neighbor and current boyfriend Ernest Brooks were arrested on suspicion of first degree murder. Brooks readily confessed to police. He said that on July 18, Therressa had come over to his place to have sex. The two were interrupted in mid-copulation by Samantha, who had come over there looking for her mother. Therressa was enraged at being interrupted. Brooks said he held his pants up and watched as she clubbed the little girl over the head with her right arm, which was wrapped in a cast as she'd broken it in a car accident a week and a half earlier.

Therressa then grabbed a pipe wrench that Brooks had laying around and smashed it into the back of Samantha's head until she stopped moving. Brooks said he helped her collect the body and dump it on the grounds of the abandoned foundry where it was later discovered. He pled guilty to abuse of a corpse, obstruction of justice, and evidence tampering, and was sentenced to 5 years in prison.

Denton Ritchie attended each day of Therressa's trial in Montgomery County Superior Court, only ducking out on the graphic photos of Samantha's body. On February 22, 1996, she was found guilt of first degree murder and sentenced to 22 to life as well as 7-1/2 years for evidence tampering, abuse of a corpse, and inducing public panic. The greater tragedy about Samantha's death is that it was easily preventable, and the numerous warning signs that she wasn't being properly cared for were ignored. At least one time Samantha knocked on a neighbor's door at 1:00 AM complaining that her mom wasn't around--she had a habit of sneaking out the window of her bedroom at night as the rental unit Therressa lived in had no air conditioning and it was sweltering inside during the Ohio summer weather. The neighbor said it wasn't her problem and told her to go away. Child Protective Services had been called to Therressa's residence once and reported that they found nothing amiss.

Therressa Richie, now in her 50s, remains incarcerated in the Dayton Correctional Institution. She was denied parole in 2010 and again in 2020. Samantha, who would have been starting kindergarten in September 1995, was laid to rest in the Bear Creek-Hillgrove Cemetery in Dayton.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14437606
I literally did give you a better word for the kind of thing you’re trying to describe. “Grounding” denotes a relation of necessary metaphysical dependence between facts. That is, the grounded fact is determined by some grounding fact necessarily. There’s a lot of literature on this. Unlike causality, it’s entirely atemporal.
If you want to say that reality is grounded by God’s existence, that’s a different argument from the kind op is describing, and from the kind of argument people like WLC employ. If you want to say that time is determined to exist by some other thing outside of time, saying it’s “caused” in any way is an inaccurate way of speaking. That’s part of why most cosmological arguments aren’t compelling; just because everything is caused inside of a spacetime medium doesn’t mean that spacetime itself is grounded. Those are two completely different relations.

Even though crime/mafia stories are usually ethnic, they're paradoxically one of the few things we have as a common culture that people kinda relate to, and they can rise to something almost like Shakespearean plays for the English or Greek tragedies. They're tragedies (and can be quite funny) where these goombas are trying to "make it" per the American Dream but they end up being undone or just as miserable (if not more so) than when they started (or they get killed and brought down).

The stories can make you think too: who is this guy, how he is related to that guy, what is he doing, etc. They deal with people's hypocrises:

https://youtu.be/bzVeLjj6Ao8

Fargo was one of the great crime movies too and it takes place in Minnesota and North Dakota, so it's also an "ethnic" film in a way but it's white people who live there and are descended from Scandinavian immigrants. Scarface took place in Miami in the 80s. The Sopranos, obviously, in New Jersey at the turn of the century. These American crime stories feel very "real" to us, like involving particular places and the real people who live there. The places or the particular time is as important as the individual characters.

That's just my theory.

>>14437573
Whether or not you agree with the political leanings of academics in whatever field, they know a lot. As far as philosophy goes, trying to interpret classic texts or dense contemporary literature yourself, without the prerequisite training, is often insufficient for understanding the key conceptual points and difficulties of a given project.
Unless you have a natural aptitude for philosophy (which is somewhat rare), there’s no substitute for learning about philosophy by discussing it with experts who know the literature on a given subject or sub-field inside and out. There are a lot of self-proclaimed and self-taught “internet philosophers” who absolutely flounder in upper level phil courses and grad seminars.
I know it sounds elitist, but there really isn’t any other way for someone who isn’t especially philosophically talented to be very knowledgeable. And even for someone who is especially talented, they wouldn’t know the extent of their talent until they’re put in a context where their abilities can be tested- a university is a perfect proving ground.
History might be another story, but that’s outside my domain of expertise.

>>14436635
> Oral traditions are made up and changed every single time they're retold.
> source: just trust me bro

I find it hard to believe that any culture would have any cohesion if, with each telling of their own history, the speaker just wholesale invents a new tradition. Details are going to be forgotten, and others are going to be added where culturally significant; the oral tradition is a way of condensing history into something that can be passed on. Nevertheless, key points of the story would remain with more or less elaboration.
It would be egregious if Homer just decided that, in his version of the Iliad, the Trojans invaded the Greeks. He’s beholden to an oral tradition that others will know is ‘true’ because they’ve heard the story before. It’s pretty disingenuous to say that a primitive culture would only have a handful of intelligent people that are qualified to pass on the oral history, when such people would’ve been apprentices of master poets, whose sole purpose is to be around to tell the great story.

All that to say: though there is potential for the oral tradition to be corrupted, doing so would’ve been antithetical to the purpose of having an oral tradition in the first place. If youre intent to just assume that anything fallible is necessarily flawed, then more than just oral traditions will seem untenable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14437646
>they don’t have the same rigor as written sources
>more room for it to go wrong
>so I assume it all went wrong

It’s actually hard to imagine how an oral culture would’ve existed, considering we live in a culture that relies on written records. In one generation of an oral culture, they would’ve had the story, and there would be no point of comparison for them to know what changed. The next generation would’ve had a version that logically followed the previous, and since the story itself persists through generations, you can know that there wouldn’t be any drastic changes that make the story seem out of place. Also consider how these cultures would’ve been primed to accept what changes did occur; they weren’t “missing” a written record, their stories were meant to evolve alongside the people. Mythological figures probably weren’t even people, but general categories that historical stories would’ve been catalogued into. As a whole oral tradition, the history remains in an almost cryptic form, and is almost incompatible to our modern concept of history.
